oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:author: Wang, Ling; Chiu, Mei Choi; Wong, Hoi Ying
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:document_title: Volterra mortality model: actuarial valuation and risk management with long-range dependence
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:spelling: Wang, Ling; Wang, L.; Chiu, Mei Choi; Chiu, M. C.; Wong, Hoi Ying; Wong, H.-Y.; Wong, Hoi-Ying

zbmath:review.zbmath:review_text:
The authors propose a novel class of Volterra mortality models that incorporate long-range dependence (LRD) into the actuarial valuation, retain tractability, and are consistent with the existing continuous-time affine mortality models.
To include the LRD, the authors suppose that the counting process \(N(t)\) of the number of deaths has an intensity \(\mu(t)=f(X(t))\) where \(X(t)\) follows a fractional Brownian motion which is equivalent to a Volterra process.
The survival probability is derived in closed form by taking into account the historical health records. The models can be used for valuing mortality-related products such as death benefits, annuities, longevity bonds, as well as for offering optimal mean-variance mortality hedging rules.
Numerical studies are conducted to examine the effect of incorporating LRD into mortality rates on various insurance products and hedging efficiency.

oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:author: Peng, Xingchun; Chen, Fenge; Wang, Wenyuan
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:document_title: Robust optimal investment and reinsurance for an insurer with inside information
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:spelling: Peng, X.; Peng, Xingchun; Peng, Xing-chun; Peng, Xing-Chun; Chen, F.; Chen, Fenge; Wang, Wenyuan; Wang, W.; Wang, W. Y.; Wang, Wen-Yuan

zbmath:review.zbmath:review_text: The authors study a robust optimal investment-reinsurance problem for an insurer who possesses inside information on the financial market and the insurance business under model uncertainty. The insurer's surplus process and the risky asset process in the financial market are assumed to be correlated jump diffusion processes with random coefficients; and the inside information is modelled by a general random variable related to the future realizations of the surplus process and the risky asset process. Under the criterion of expected utility maximization, and by incorporating Knightian uncertainty into the model, they establish an adapted stochastic differential game problem with a nonstandard performance functional, which aims to select the robust optimal investment-reinsurance strategy for the insurer with inside information.

oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:spelling: Mammen, Enno; Mammen, E.; Martínez-Miranda, M. D.; Martínez Miranda, María Dolores; Martínez-Miranda, María Dolores; Miranda, María Dolores Martínez; Martínez-Miranda, Maria Dolores; Martínez Miranda, M. D.; Martìnez-Miranda, M. D.; Nielsen, Jens Perch; Nielsen, Jens P.; Nielsen, J. P.; Perch Nielsen, Jens; Nielsen, Jans Perch; Nielsen, Jens; Nielsen, J.; Vogt, Michael; Vogt, Michael P.; Vogt, M.

zbmath:review.zbmath:review_text: The authors consider a generalization of the chain ladder methodology. Instead of the assumption $f(x,y) = h(x) g(y)$ the authors introduce an extended version based on the density $f(x,y) = h(x) g(y) k(x+y)$ with a so called calendar effect $k$. Two main examples are outstanding liabilities in insurance ($x$ time point of claims, $y$ time delay up to reporting the claim) and fertility analysis ($x$ birth date of the mother, $y$ age of the mother at time of birth of a child). In section 2 the authors give conditions such that $h,g,k$ are uniquely determined, section 3 describes the estimation procedure, section 4 the forecasting method (by extrapolating the function $k$), section 5 contains 3 theorems of theoretical properties of the estimators. Section 6 contains case studies of the two main examples: Claims from motor business in Cyprus and analysis of fertility rates with data from Italy and US. The final section 7 contains simulation results.

oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:author: Bravo, Jorge M.; Nunes, João Pedro Vidal
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:document_title: Pricing longevity derivatives via Fourier transforms
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:spelling: Bravo, Jorge M.; Bravo, Jorge Miguel; Nunes, João P.; Nunes, João Pedro Vidal; Vidal Nunes, João Pedro; Nunes, J. P.

zbmath:review.zbmath:review_text: The paper provides a Fourier transform approach for European-style longevity option pricing. The guidelines related to the valuation of longevity derivatives with different payoff structures, by means of a Fourier transform approach, are described; these guidelines, that cover option-type contracts, S-forwards and longevity swaps, provide the basis for the pricing model. Then, the analytical pricing model for longevity derivatives under a risk-adjusted probability pricing measure is developed within a stochastic framework, where both the mortality intensity and interest rates are described by means of a continuous-time affine jump-diffusion stochastic process. Moreover the model calibration is in-depth; numerical examples about the valuation of longevity derivatives complete the study and show the contribution of the results presented in the paper to applied cases. Some technical issues can be obtained by a supplementary file available through the link in Appendix.

oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:author: Schmeck, Maren Diane; Schmidli, Hanspeter
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:document_title: Mortality options: the point of view of an insurer
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:spelling: Schmeck, Maren Diane; Schmidli, Hanspeter; Schmidli, H.

zbmath:review.zbmath:review_text:
The authors consider a life insurer in a discrete time framework who is able to buy a securitization product to hedge mortality. Two cohorts are considered: one underlying the securitization product and one for the portfolio of the insurer. In a general setting, the authors show that there exists a unique strategy that maximizes the insurer's expected utility from terminal wealth.
Numerical illustrations of the approach are demonstrated in the context of a Gompertz-Makeham model, where the realized survival probabilities can fluctuate moderately within an \(\epsilon\)-corridor, as well as in the context of a toy model for mortality shocks. In both examples the insurer can hedge longevity risk by trading in a survival bond.

oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:author: Denuit, Michel; Robert, Christian Y.
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:document_title: From risk sharing to pure premium for a large number of heterogeneous losses
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:source: Insur. Math. Econ. 96, 116-126 (2021); corrigendum and addendum ibid. 101, 640-644 (2021).
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:spelling: Denuit, Michel; Denuit, Michel M.; Denuit, M.; Denuit, M; Robert, Christian Y.; Robert, Christian; Robert, C. Y.; Robert, C.; Robert, Christian Yann

zbmath:review.zbmath:review_text:
Let \(\{X_1,X_2,\ldots,X_n\}\) be a collection mutually independent non-negative random variables representing monetary losses of \(n\) participants to an insurance pool. Denote by \(h_{i,n}(s)\) the amount participant \(i\in\{1,2,\ldots,n\}\) contributes to the pool, where \(s=\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_i\) is the sum of the realizations \(x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_n\) of random variables \(X_1,X_2,\ldots,X_n\).
A fair \textit{risk sharing rule} is an allocation scheme such that, for all \(n\in\mathbb{N}\) there exist measurable functions \(h_{1,n},h_{2,n},\ldots,h_{n,n}\) satisfying two requirements: \[ \sum_{i=1}^{n}h_{i,n}(s)=s \ \text{ for }\ s\geqslant 0; \] \[ \mathbb{E}\left(h_{i,n}(S_n))\right)=\mathbb{E}X_i\ \text{ for }\ i\in\{1,2,\ldots,n\}. \] The first condition means that the total risk \(S_n=X_1+X_2+\ldots+X_n\) is entirely allocated among the \(n\) participants, and the second condition ensures actuarial fairness.
Authors of the paper study the behaviour of three \textit{risk sharing rules} when the size of the pool becomes large.

oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:rights: Content generated by zbMATH Open, such as reviews, classifications, software, or author disambiguation data, are distributed under CC-BY-SA 4.0. This defines the license for the whole dataset, which also contains non-copyrighted bibliographic metadata and reference data derived from I4OC (CC0). Note that the API only provides a subset of the data in the zbMATH Open Web interface. In several cases, third-party information, such as abstracts, cannot be made available under a suitable license through the API. In those cases, we replaced the data with the string 'zbMATH Open Web Interface contents unavailable due to conflicting licenses.'

oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:author: Cavalletti, Fabio; Mondino, Andrea
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:document_title: New formulas for the Laplacian of distance functions and applications
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:spelling: Cavalletti, Fabio; Cavalletti, F.; Mondino, Andrea; Mondino, A.

zbmath:review.zbmath:review_text:
A \((K,N)\)-measure contraction property (the MCP\((K,N)\)-spaces for short) and the \((K,N)\)-curvature-dimension condition (the CD\((K,N)\) for short,\(K\in\mathbb{R}, N\in[n,\infty]\)) have had an important role in several classical problems of the calculus of variations, geometric measure theory and mathematical physics. Several authors studied the geometry of \((K,N)\)-curvature-dimension condition and the \((K,N)\)-curvature-dimension [\textit{K.-T. Sturm}, Acta Math. 196, No. 1, 65--131 (2006; Zbl 1105.53035); ibid. 196, No. 1, 133--177 (2006; Zbl 1106.53032); \textit{G. Wei} and \textit{W. Wylie}, J. Differ. Geom. 83, No. 2, 377--405 (2009; Zbl 1189.53036); \textit{P. W. Y. Lee} et al., Discrete Contin. Dyn. Syst. 36, No. 1, 303--321 (2016; Zbl 1326.53043); \textit{J. Lott} and \textit{C. Villani}, Ann. Math. (2), 169, No. 3, 903--991 (2009; Zbl 1178.53038); \textit{L. Rifford}, Math. Control Relat. Fields 3, No. 4, 467--487 (2013; Zbl 1275.53034); \textit{L. Rizzi}, Calc. Var. Partial Differ. Equ. 55 No. 3, Article ID 60, 20 p. (2016; Zbl 1352.53026); \textit{F. Baudoin} and \textit{N. Garofalo}, J. Eur. Math. Soc. (JEMS), 19, No. 1, 151--219 (2017; Zbl 1359.53018); \textit{D. Barilari} and \textit{L. Rizzi}, Commun. Contemp. Math., 20, 6, Article ID 1750081, 24 p. (2018; Zbl 1398.53038)].
The principal objective in this paper is to prove an exact representation formula for the Laplacian of the distance (and more generally for an arbitrary \(1\)-Lipschitz function) in the framework of metric measure spaces satisfying Ricci curvature lower bounds in a synthetic sense (more precisely in essentially nonbranching MCP\((K,N)\)-spaces). Also the authors have proved the equivalence of CD\((K,N)\) and a dimensional Bochner inequality on signed distance functions. Moreover the authors obtain a measure-theoretic splitting theorem for infinitesimally Hilbertian, essentially nonbranching spaces satisfying MCP\((0,N)\).

oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:author: Boedihardjo, March T.
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:document_title: \(C^\ast\)-algebras isomorphically representable on \(l^p\)
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:spelling: Boedihardjo, March T.; Boedihardjo, March

zbmath:review.zbmath:review_text:
A Banach algebra \(A\) is (isometrically) representable on some Banach space \(X\) if there exists an (isometric) isomorphism between \(A\) and a closed subalgebra of the bounded, linear operators on \(X\).
It is well known that every C*-algebra is isometrically representable on some Hilbert space. On the other hand, it was shown in [\textit{E. Gardella} and \textit{H.~Thiel}, Math. Z. 294, No. 3--4, 1341--1354 (2020; Zbl 1456.46042)] that a C*-algebra is isometrically representable on some \(L_p\)-space for \(p\in[1,\infty)\setminus\{2\}\) if and only if the C*-algebra is commutative.
Turning to isomorphic representability on \(L_p\)-spaces, using that the Hilbert space \(\ell_2\) is isomorphic to a complemented subspace of \(L_p=L_p([0,1])\), we see that every C*-algebra that is representable on \(\ell_2\) (in particular, every separable C*-algebra) is also representable on \(L_p\), for every \(p\in[1,\infty)\).
This paper complements these results by showing that a C*-algebra is representable on the \(L_p\)-space \(\ell^p(J)\) for \(p\in(1,\infty)\setminus\{2\}\) and some set \(J\) if and only if the C*-algebra is residually finite-dimensional. It remains open if the result also holds for \(p=1\).

oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:author: Abedin, Farhan; Kitagawa, Jun
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:document_title: Exponential convergence of parabolic optimal transport on bounded domains
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:spelling: Abedin, Farhan; Kitagawa, Jun

zbmath:review.zbmath:review_text: The authors study the asymptotic behavior of solutions to the second boundary value problem for a parabolic PDE of Monge-Ampère type arising from optimal mass transport. They are able to prove an exponential rate of convergence for solutions of this evolution equation to the stationary solution of the optimal transport problem. They obtain this important exponential convergence and the control of the oscillation in time of solutions to the parabolic equation by deriving a differential Harnack inequality for a special class of functions that solve the linearized problem and by certain techniques specific to mass transport. Additionally, in the course of the proof, they discover an interesting connection with the pseudo-Riemannian framework introduced by Kim and McCann in the context of optimal transport.

oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:author: Castillejos, Jorge; Evington, Samuel
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:document_title: Nuclear dimension of simple stably projectionless \(C^\ast\)-algebras
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:spelling: Castillejos, Jorge; Evington, Samuel

zbmath:review.zbmath:review_text:
A \(\mathrm{C}^\ast\)-algebra \(A\) is said to be \(\mathcal{Z}\)-stable if \(A\cong A\otimes\mathcal{Z}\), where \(\mathcal{Z}\) is the Jiang-Su algebra. The class of simple \(\mathcal{Z}\)-stable \(\mathrm{C}^\ast\)-algebras has been the main focus of the classification program of simple separable nuclear \(\mathrm{C}^\ast\)-algebras in the last decade, as many naturally arising \(\mathrm{C}^\ast\)-algebras are \(\mathcal{Z}\)-stable, and on the other hand, without the assumption of \(\mathcal{Z}\)-stability, counterexamples have been found for the classification using conventional $K$-theoretical invariant.
For simple separable nuclear nonelementary \(\mathrm{C}^\ast\)-algebras, the \(\mathcal{Z}\)-stability was conjectured by \textit{A. S. Toms} and \textit{W. Winter} [J. Funct. Anal. 256, No. 5, 1311--1340 (2009; Zbl 1184.46061)] to be equivalent to finite nuclear dimension, where the nuclear dimension was introduced by \textit{W. Winter} and \textit{J. Zacharias} [Adv. Math. 224, No. 2, 461--498 (2010; Zbl 1201.46056)] as a \(\mathrm{C}^\ast\)-algebra analogue of the topological covering dimension. It was shown in [\textit{W. Winter}, Invent. Math. 187, No. 2, 259--342 (2012; Zbl 1280.46041)] that all simple unital separable nonelementary \(\mathrm{C}^\ast\)-algebras with finite nuclear dimension are \(\mathcal{Z}\)-stable, and then this result was generalized to nonunital \(\mathrm{C}^\ast\)-algebras in [\textit{A. Tikuisis}, Math. Ann. 358, No. 3--4, 729--778 (2014; Zbl 1319.46043)].
For the converse, a breakthrough has been made in [the first author et. al., Invent. Math. 224, No. 1, 245--290 (2021; Zbl 1467.46055)] where all simple unital separable nuclear nonelementary \(\mathcal{Z}\)-stable \(\mathrm{C}^\ast\)-algebras have been shown to have nuclear dimension at most \(1\). In the present paper, the assumption of being unital is removed, and hence it completes the equivalence between \(\mathcal{Z}\)-stability and finite nuclear dimension for simple separable nuclear nonelementary \(\mathrm{C}^\ast\)-algebras.

oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:author: Bella, Peter; Schäffner, Mathias
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:document_title: On the regularity of minimizers for scalar integral functionals with \((p,q)\)-growth
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:spelling: Bella, Peter; Bella, P.; Schäffner, Mathias

zbmath:review.zbmath:review_text: In this paper, the authors study the minimizers of scalar autonomous integral functionals with \((p, q)\)-growth. This kind of funtionals was introduced and widely studied by Marcellini. He proved, under suitable contidions on the exponents, the Lipschitz continuity of the solutions. Here, the authors improve the Marcellini's results establishing Lipschitz regularity under the condition \(\frac{q}{p}< 1 + \frac{2}{n-1}\) for \(n\geq 3\).

oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:author: Ducasse, Romain
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:document_title: Propagation properties of reaction-diffusion equations in periodic domains
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:spelling: Ducasse, Romain

zbmath:review.zbmath:review_text: The author studies the propagation properties of general reaction-diffusion equation with periodic coefficient and periodic domain. The results also answer the open problem by \textit{H. Berestycki} et al. [J. Eur. Math. Soc. (JEMS) 7, No. 2, 173--213 (2005; Zbl 1142.35464)]. It provides us that the critical speed of pulsating traveling front and the invasion speed are not everywhere equal. The author extends the classical Freidlin-Gärtner formula to periodic equations and derives some bounds on the speed of invasion using estimates on the heat kernel, and investgates the critical speed of fronts.

oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:author: Luiz, Atílio G.; Campos, C. N.; Richter, R. Bruce
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:document_title: On 0-rotatable graceful caterpillars
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:spelling: Luiz, Atílio G.; Luiz, A. G.; Campos, C. N.; Campos, C.; Richter, R. Bruce; Richter, R. B.; Richter, Robert; Richter, Bruce; Richter, R.; Bruce Richter, R.; Richter, Bruce R.

zbmath:review.zbmath:review_text: An injection $f : V(T)\to\{0,1,\dots,|E(T)|\}$ of a tree $T$ is a graceful labeling if $\{|f(u)-f(v)|:uv\in E(T)\}=\{1,\dots,|E(T)|\}$. A tree $T$ is 0-rotatable if for any $v\in V(T)$ there exists a graceful labeling $f$ of $T$ such that $f(v) = 0$. In this paper, the authors prove that some families of caterpillars are 0-rotatable. Among them are all caterpillars with diameter five or six and all caterpillars $T$ with $\operatorname{diam}(T) \geq 7$ such that for every non-leaf vertex $v\in V(T)$ the number of leaves adjacent to $v$ is even and at least $2 + 2((\operatorname{diam}(T)-1)\bmod{2})$. These results show that for each integer $d\geq 5$ there exist 0-rotatable caterpillars with diameter $d$ and arbitrary number of vertices.

oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:author: Feghali, Carl
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:document_title: Reconfiguring 10-colourings of planar graphs
oai_zb_preview:zbmath.zbmath:spelling: Feghali, Carl

zbmath:review.zbmath:review_text:
In this paper, the author considers finite, undirected graphs that do not contain loops or parallel edges. For an integer \(d\geq 1\), a graph \(G=(V, E)\) is called \(d\)-degenerate if every subgraph of \(G\) has minimum degree at most \(d\). Trees and planar graphs are examples of \(1\)-degenerate and 5-degenerate graphs, respectively.
For an integer \(k\geq 1\) and a graph \(G=(V,E)\), a function \(c:V\rightarrow \{1,\dots,k\}\) is called a \(k\)-coloring of \(G\) if for any edge \(e=uv\in E\), we have \(c(u)\neq c(v)\). Let \(R_k(G)\) be a graph, whose vertices are all \(k\)-colorings of \(G\), and two \(k\)-colorings of \(G\) form an edge in \(R_k(G)\) if and only if they differ only on color of exactly one vertex. The main result of the paper is the following:
Theorem: \(R_{10}(G)\) has diameter at most \(\frac{n(n+1)}{2}\) for all planar graphs \(G\) on \(n\) vertices.
The result of the author deals with a conjecture of \textit{L. Cereceda} [Mixing graph colourings. London: London School of Economics (PhD Thesis) (2007)], which states that for \(l\geq k+2\) and every \(k\)-degenerate graph on \(n\) vertices \(R_{l}(G)\) has diameter \(O(n^2)\).
